Award.AwardTitle: Holomorphic Dynamics in one and several variables
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dynamical systems are mathematical models that allow researchers to study physical phenomenon that evolve with time: from motion of the planets to stock markets. The PI studies holomorphic dynamics, which refers to iterations of certain complex-valued maps that admit a rich geometry. The subject has numerous interactions with other areas of mathematics, in particular with the important subjects of Teichmuller Theory and Multidimensional Complex Analysis. The PI will continue her work concerning geometric aspects of holomorphic dynamics and in particular she will work to extend certain parts of the the theory from dynamics of one complex variable to several complex variables. The PI will continue to provide special topical lectures to undergraduate and graduate students in the hope of exciting the interest of students in the field of dynamical systems and, more broadly, in mathematics.

The link between holomorphic dynamics and Teichmuller Theory can be to a large extent explained by holomorphic motions. The PI, together with collaborators, suggest a geometric approach to the proof of Slodkowski's lambda lemma. We relate holomorphic motions to the technique of filling totally real manifolds by holomorphic discs. We plan to use this approach to investigate the h-principle for holomorphic motions over Riemann surfaces. Thurston's theorem on postcritically finite rational maps is one of the central results in one-dimensional holomorphic dynamics. Building on Thurston's work, A. Epstein introduced deformation spaces, which give a unified approach to transversality results in holomorphic dynamics. The PI, together with collaborators, will investigate certain topological properties of these deformation spaces. In one-dimensional holomorphic dynamics to a large extent the orbits of critical points determine the dynamics of the map. For an automorphism of complex plane there are no critical points however there are various analogs of the critical points in different dynamically defined regions. The research will investigate these critical loci and their application to the construction of topological models. We also study the non-linearizable germs of analytic diffeomorphisms of complex plane.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dynamical systems have application in physics, biology, engineering, etc. They occur as models for orbits of planets, weather predictions, biological rhythms. Some of the dynamical systems that are easiest to state are obtained by the iteration of a single map, viewed as a function from the real $n$-dimensional space to the real $n$-dimensional space. Some of these functions have extensions to complex In the complex setting one can make use of complex analytic and geometric tools that are not available in the real one.

PI works in complex dynamics in one and several complex variables. During the tenure of the award, PI developed the following areas: study of local dynamics (hedgehogs for multidimensional maps), critical points of multipliers, and deformation spaces for rational maps. 

Hedgehogs: The study of local dynamics goes back to the 19th century when Koening proved that a one dimensional germ of a holomorphic map f(z)=\lambda z+o(z^2), with |\lambda| different from 0 and 1, is linearizable. It implies that for such germs local dynamics is the same as dynamics of linear maps (up to change of coordinates). If multiplier lies on the unit circle, then the germ can be non-linearizable. If \lamda=e^{i\theta}, \theta is not rational, and the map f is non-linearizable, then the origin is called a Cremer point. The dynamics of the Cremer point is rich and hard to to visualize. A serious advancement was made in 1990's by Perez-Marco who proved the existence of interesting invariant compact sets near the Cremer fixed point, called hedgehogs. Using deep results from the theory of analytic circle diffeomorphisms developed by Yoccoz, Perez-Marco showed that even if the map on a neighborhood of the origin is not conjugate to an irrational rotation, the points of the hedgehog are recurrent and still move under the influence of the rotation. The results of Perez-Marco are purely one dimensional since they heavily rely on uniformization techniques. In a joint work with M.Lyubich, R.Radu and R.Tanase, we constructed hedgehogs for 2-dimensional germs with semi-indiferent fixed points (one multiplier is attracting, the other is on the unit circle). Our methods are topological in nature they will encourage the search for topological methods in the study of hedgehogs for neutral fixed points. 

 Critical Points of Multipliers. One dimensional holomorphic dynamics studies the iterates of a map $z\mapsto f(z)$, where $f(z)$ is a rational function (or more generally, an entire function or a germ). The multiplier of a periodic orbit of period $n$ is the derivative of the $n$-th iterate of the map at a point in the orbit. If we consider a space of rational functions that depend on a parameter, and start from an orbit  with a multiplier different from 1, then the multiplier extends to a neighborhood of the map as an analytic function of the parameter.  If the parameter space is algebraic then the multiplier extends as a multivalued algebraic function to the parameter space. As pointed out by J-C. Yoccoz, critical points of the multipliers are related to the hyperbolicity conjectute.  A rational map is hyperbolic if the forward iterate of each critical point converges to a periodic orbit. Hyperbolic maps are structually stable on the Julia set. Hyperbolicity conjecture that goes back to Fatou states that hyperbolic maps are dense in the parameter space. In a joint work with I.Gorbovickis we started a systematic study of the critical points of multipliers. We have shown that the critical points of multipliers equidistribute on the boundary of the Mandelbrot set. However, the accumulation set of the critical points of multipliers is larger then the boundary of the Mandelbrot. We have shown that it is bounded, connected and, somewhat surprisingly, contains all of the Mandelbrot set, and it has non-empty interior outside of the Mandelbrot set. 

 Deformation spaces of rational maps. If the parameter space of polynomials or rational functions is higher dimensional, it is hard to visualize and study. It is natural to consider curves (varieties) defined by certain postcritical relations.  The first such examples were $\Per_n$ curves introduced and studied by J.Milnor. A $\Per_n$ curve in the space of quadratic rational maps (or cubic polynomial) with marked critical points consists of the maps for which the first critical point belongs to the cycle of length $n$. 

 Building on ideas of W.Thurston, A.Epstein suggested deformation space approach to the study of varieties defined by postcrtically finite relations. PI together with collaborators studied topological properties of the deformation spaces. We explained the behavior of the deformation spaces at infinity in terms of arithmetically equalizing curves (analogs of W.Thurston's invariant for postcritically finite maps). We have provided examples of deformation spaces that are non-contractibl,e thus answering a question of A.Epstein. We introduced groups of self-equivalences of deformation spaces, and explained how arithmetically equalizing curves give rise to self-equivalences.
